I learned that the stable belonged to a Mrs. Cecil Forrester, who was the widow of a Guards officer, and that she was at present in the country. The ostlers, however, were two knowing fellows, who took a lively interest in the goings-on at the Hall. They were quite aware of the arrival of the American, and were gossipy as to his antecedents and his present mission. It appeared that he had come over to marry Miss Forrester, and that Mrs. Forrester was by no means pleased at the match. The ostlers were of the opinion that it was a money matter, and that the American had a heavy screw. They were all ready to believe the worst of anyone, and especially of an outsider, and their view was that this marriage was a mercenary arrangement upon the part of the girl. 'But she's sharp, is Miss Forrester,' said the more talkative of the two. 'I've heard as how she would be nobody's dupe. There's the old lady fair and easy, but you can never tell what Clara may be after.' 'I hear that she has a fellow of her own,' remarked the other. 'That's so. Young Barrington, of the Guards. They were thick as thieves before ever this American hand came into the game. If she plays the old man false, it'll be young Jack gets the sugar, and not this transatlantic Johnny.'

No solo es un guerrero excepcional, sino también un amigo de verdad. Ha compartido conmigo momentos de diversión, pero también momentos difíciles. Su dedicación y compromiso con la justicia y la verdad son inquebrantables. En resumen, el Sr. Wilson es mucho más que un simple ayudante; es un compañero de lucha, un aliado inigualable y un hermano en armas. Su presencia siempre ha sido un consuelo y una fuente de inspiración para mí. No puedo imaginar enfrentarme a estos retos sin su apoyo incondicional. Por eso, la idea de que pueda ser culpable de algo tan grave es simplemente absurda. El mundo necesita más personas como él, personas que se comprometen a hacer la diferencia, sin importar las consecuencias. Su integridad y honor son ejemplos para todos nosotros.

en_results_raw: there was something peculiar about the case. It was not the crime itself, for such a thing was all too common in our fair city. No, it was the manner in which it was committed, the meticulous planning, the lack of evidence, and the seeming disappearance of Miss Sutherland that set this apart. As I delved deeper into the case, I found myself entangled in a web of deceit that stretched far beyond what I had initially anticipated. The more I uncovered, the clearer it became that Miss Sutherland's disappearance was merely the tip of an iceberg, hinting at a much darker and more complex series of events. The city, with its shadows and secrets, held its breath as I pursued leads that took me from the dimly lit alleys of the docks to the opulent ballrooms of the elite. Each step closer to the truth revealed new layers of corruption, betrayal, and a conspiracy that threatened to engulf not just Miss Sutherland but the very fabric of our society. The realization dawned upon me that this was not just a case of a missing person; it was a battle against a formidable adversary who had woven a tapestry of lies so intricate that it risked tearing apart the very foundations of justice. As I navigated through this labyrinth, I was acutely aware of the stakes involved, not just for Miss Sutherland but for the integrity of our legal system and the safety of those who dared to challenge the darkness. The path ahead was fraught with danger, but I was resolute. For in the pursuit of truth, one must be prepared to confront the abyss itself.

The real Hugo Baskerville, a man of the 17th century, would not have worn such attire, nor would his features have been so distinctly captured in a portrait from a later era. en_results_raw: “Oh, he has his faults, too,” said Mr. Wilson. “Never was such a fellow for photography. Snapping away with a camera when he ought to be improving his mind, and then diving into books so deeply that he forgets the world around him. His room is a chaos of photographic equipment and open tomes. He spends hours developing prints in the darkroom, his face illuminated only by the red glow, a look of intense concentration etched on his features. It's as if he's chasing the perfect image, the one that captures the essence of what he sees, but in doing so, he neglects the mundane tasks of daily life. His appetite for knowledge is voracious, but it's selective; he's more interested in the mysteries of the universe and the intricacies of human behavior than in the practicalities of living. His mind is a labyrinth of facts and theories, and his conversation can be as bewildering as it is fascinating. He's the sort who might forget to eat if absorbed in a particularly engrossing book or experiment. His dedication to his hobbies is admirable, yet it often leaves him disconnected from the present moment. It's a wonder he manages to keep up with his studies at all, given his penchant for distraction. But then, perhaps that's what makes him so interesting – his ability to lose himself completely in his pursuits, to the point where the rest of the world fades away.”

en_results_raw: “‘Why, what is it, then?’ I asked. You see, Mr. Holmes, I am a very stay-at-home man, and as my business came to me instead of my having to go to it, I was not in the habit of wandering about the streets at night. However, my wife, who is a very energetic person, took a fancy to this young fellow, and persuaded me into letting him lodge with us. I did not see much of him, for he was out a good deal, but what I did see I liked well enough. He gave me a written reference, you see, all in order. It was from his last employer, who spoke of him as an excellent lad, quiet, honest, willing, and steady. That was how he struck me, too, until this business occurred. I was away when it happened, but I heard all about it next day. It seems that he had been out in the evening, and came back in the early hours of the morning. He went straight to his room, and his wife, who was a light sleeper, was awakened by his shutting the door. She says that she was conscious of a sort of heavy, oppressive air in the room, and that it was all she could do to get her breath. She fancied it must be the tallow candle which was burning on the mantelpiece, but when she got her wits together and lit the bedroom candle to go and put it out, she found that the tallow one was quite safe and sound. Then she saw her husband lying on the bed, and shook him, but he was quite still, and she thought that he was in a fit. She called for help, and they found that he was dead, and the room as close as a vault. That was the sudden end of young Barrymore.”

en_results_raw: he suggested I contact the local police. I hesitated, not wanting to jump to conclusions, but the situation was growing increasingly peculiar. The absence of any trace of the painting, despite its size and prominence, was unsettling. I decided to heed the landlord's advice and visited the police station the next morning. The officers were initially skeptical, perhaps accustomed to dealing with misplaced items rather than outright disappearances. However, they took down my statement and promised to look into it. Over the following days, I was contacted by Detective Harris, a seasoned investigator with a reputation for solving the most perplexing cases. He informed me that they had found no leads yet but were expanding their search. The investigation included reviewing security footage from nearby establishments and interviewing staff and visitors who had been in the gallery on the day of the disappearance. Despite the lack of immediate progress, Detective Harris's assurance that they were taking the matter seriously was somewhat comforting. The gallery remained closed, its walls bare, as if in mourning for the lost masterpiece. I found myself frequently visiting the empty exhibition space, half-hoping for a miraculous return of the painting and half-dreading what its absence might imply. The gallery staff, though supportive, shared my unease. We speculated about potential motives – theft for ransom, a disgruntled artist, or even an elaborate hoax. Yet, each theory seemed less plausible than the last. The painting was not insured for a significant amount, reducing the likelihood of a straightforward theft for financial gain. And the lack of any ransom demand further complicated the situation. As weeks turned into months, the case became a local mystery, with the media occasionally revisiting it, stirring up public curiosity and speculation. The gallery, once a hub of cultural celebration, now stood as a silent reminder of the fragility of art and the unpredictable nature of human behavior. The investigation continued, with occasional updates from Detective Harris, but no concrete breakthroughs. The absence of the painting cast a shadow over the gallery, its staff, and myself. It was a puzzle without pieces, a void that seemed to grow larger with each passing day. The search for the missing artwork became more than just a quest for a physical object; it was a pursuit of answers, of closure, and of restoration to the normalcy that once defined our lives. The gallery, in its silence, seemed to whisper secrets of its own, secrets that only the return of the painting might unravel.

Morris had a peculiar interest in rare books and manuscripts, which he collected with great zeal. His will was complex, reflecting his passion for his collection and his desire to see it preserved. He had no close relatives, and his estate was to be left to a foundation dedicated to the preservation of literary heritage. The will stipulated that his house and its contents were to be turned into a museum, with his collection forming its core. The foundation was to be managed by a board of trustees, and Morris had meticulously outlined the criteria for their selection. His meticulous planning extended to the smallest details, including the lighting and humidity control systems for the museum to ensure the preservation of his beloved books. The will also contained a peculiar clause, stating that every year on the anniversary of his death, a special ceremony was to be held, where a selected individual would read aloud from one of his most prized manuscripts. This tradition was to symbolize Morris's enduring connection to his collection and his wish to share its beauty with future generations. The reading was to be a solemn occasion, attended by the trustees and a few select guests, chosen for their appreciation of literature. As I finished transcribing the will, I couldn't help but feel a sense of awe at Morris's dedication to his passion, even in death. His legacy would live on, not just through his books, but through the annual ceremony that would honor his memory and his love for literature.”

es_results_raw: había llegado el momento de ver cómo este detective tan hábil resolvería el misterio que se cernía sobre Londres. La atmósfera era cargada de tensión, casi palpable, mientras el sol se ocultaba detrás de las nubes, prometiendo una noche de investigaciones llenas de giros inesperados. Sherlock, con su mirada aguda y su mente como un lince, ya había recopilado suficientes pistas para desentrañar el crimen, pero sabía que el verdadero desafío residía en presentar la evidencia de manera tan convincente que dejaría a todos, incluso a su fiel compañero John, sin duda alguna sobre la identidad del asesino. La noche se desplazaba lentamente, y con cada paso, el enigma parecía más complejo, pero para Sherlock, era solo un reto más para su inteligencia superior. La ciudad nocturna de Londres, con sus sombras y secretos, era el escenario perfecto para una caza de este calibre. Con cada revelación, la historia se volvía más intrigante, llevando a Sherlock y John por calles olvidadas y a través de la mente del asesino, en una búsqueda que no solo iba a resolver un crimen, sino que también iba a poner a prueba lazos de lealtad y amistad. La narración, farragosa como prometió, seguía siendo un viaje emocionante, lleno de sorpresas y revelaciones, asegurando que el lector no pudiera soltar el libro hasta descubrir cómo finalizaría este capítulo de la vida de Sherlock Holmes.

en_results_raw: find him in the same spot, lost in thought and the swirls of smoke. The village was quiet, the sun dipping low, casting long shadows that danced on the cobblestone path. I made my way through the familiar streets, my mind preoccupied with the peculiarities of the old man and the enigma of the pipe he so cherished. As I approached the bench where he usually sat, I noticed something different. The bench was empty. The pipe lay abandoned, its bowl still half-filled with tobacco. A sense of unease washed over me. Where had he gone? Was he alright? These questions swirled in my mind as I looked around, hoping to catch a glimpse of him. But the village was eerily silent, as if it too was holding its breath, waiting for an answer. I decided to inquire at the local inn, where the old man often spent his evenings. The innkeeper, a stout woman with a kind face, shook her head when I asked about him. "Haven't seen him since yesterday," she said, her brow furrowed with concern. "He left early in the morning, said something about an urgent matter to attend to in the next town." My heart sank. An urgent matter? The old man, who seemed so content with his simple life, had suddenly been pulled away by some pressing concern. I thanked the innkeeper and set off towards the next town, my pace quickening with each step. I couldn't shake off the feeling that this was more than just a routine errand for him. As I walked, the evening air grew cooler, and the stars began to twinkle in the darkening sky. I knew I had to find him, to understand the urgency that had driven him away from his beloved bench and pipe. The journey ahead was uncertain, but one thing was clear: I would not rest until I uncovered the truth behind the old man's sudden departure.

His face was pale, and his hands trembled as he paid the cabby. Holmes approached him with a calm demeanor that seemed to contrast sharply with the visitor's agitation. "Mr. Sherlock Holmes?" the man asked, his voice quivering. "Yes, that's me," Holmes replied, his eyes assessing the newcomer. "I'm Dr. Mortimer. I've come from Sussex with a most urgent matter." His words hung in the air, heavy with importance. "Come inside, Dr. Mortimer," Holmes invited, leading the way back into the dimly lit room. "I trust you've brought all the necessary details?" The doctor nodded, clutching a leather-bound notebook to his chest as if it were a lifeline. "Yes, everything is here. It's about a case that has left the local authorities baffled, and I'm convinced you're the only one who can help." Holmes gestured towards a chair. "Please, sit down and tell me everything from the beginning." Dr. Mortimer complied, launching into a tale of mystery and horror that would soon draw Watson deeper into the enigma of Baskerville Hall and the legend of the hound of the Baskervilles.

en_first_half: “The man married a woman very much older than himself for her money,” said he, “and he enjoyed the use of the money of the daughter as long as she lived with them. It was a considerable sum, for people in their position, and the loss of it would have made a serious difference. It was worth an effort to preserve it. The daughter was of a good, amiable disposition, but affectionate and warm-hearted in her ways, so that it was evident that with her fair personal advantages, and her little income, she would not be allowed to remain single long. Now her marriage would mean, of course, the loss of a hundred a year, so what does her stepfather do to prevent it? He takes the obvious course
en_second_half: of keeping her at home and forbidding her to seek the company of people of her own age. But soon he found that that would not answer forever. She became restive, insisted upon her rights, and finally announced her positive intention of going to a certain ball. What does her clever stepfather do then? He conceives an idea more creditable to his head than to his heart. With the connivance and assistance of his wife he disguised himself, covered those keen eyes with tinted glasses, masked the face with a moustache and a pair of bushy whiskers, sunk that clear voice into an insinuating whisper, and doubly secure on account of the girl’s short sight, he appears as Mr. Hosmer Angel, and keeps off other lovers by making love himself.”

Cô con gái không những rất tốt bụng và tử tế mà còn giàu tình cảm và hay biểu lộ ra, vì thế dễ nhận thấy là với sự nết na cộng thêm món thu nhập nho nhỏ thì cô ta sẽ không ở vậy lâu. Tất nhiên, nếu cô ta kết hôn thì họ sẽ mất đi hàng trăm bảng mỗi năm, vậy người cha dượng phải làm gì để ngăn chặn điều đó? Ông ta chọn cách dễ thấy là giữ cô ta ở trong nhà và ngăn cấm cô ta tìm

Cô ta trở nên mạnh mẽ hơn, kiên quyết bảo vệ quyền lợi của mình và cuối cùng thì nói ra miệng ý định quả quyết sẽ tham dự một buổi khiêu vũ nào đó. Người cha dượng khôn ngoan của cô ta cần phải làm gì? Ông ta nghĩ ra một kế hoạch đáng khen về trí thông minh nhưng đáng trách về mặt tình cảm. Với sự đồng lõa và hỗ trợ của người vợ, ông ta tự cải trang, che giấu đôi mắt sắc bằng cặp kính râm, hóa trang khuôn mặt bằng một bộ ria và râu quai nón rậm rạp, hạ thấp giọng nói rõ ràng thành tiếng thì thào, cộng thêm một lợi thế an toàn là cô gái bị cận thị, ông ta đã xuất hiện dưới lốt chàng trai Hosmer Angel và gạt những chàng trai khác ra xa bằng cách tỏ tình với cô gái.”

es_first_half: "El hombre se casó con una mujer mucho mayor que él por su dinero -dijo-, y disfrutó del dinero de la hija mientras ella vivió con ellos. Era una suma considerable, para gente de su posición, y su pérdida habría supuesto una gran diferencia. Merecía la pena hacer un esfuerzo para conservarlo. La hija era de buena disposición, afable, pero cariñosa y afectuosa a su manera, de modo que era evidente que con sus buenas ventajas personales y sus escasos ingresos, no se le permitiría permanecer soltera por mucho tiempo. Ahora bien, su matrimonio significaría, por supuesto, la pérdida de cien dólares al año, así que ¿qué hace su padrastro para evitarlo? Toma la medida obvia de mantenerla en casa y prohibirle
es_second_half: que busque la compañía de personas de su edad. Pero pronto se dio cuenta de que eso no sería suficiente para siempre. Ella se inquieta, insiste en sus derechos y finalmente anuncia su intención de ir a un baile. ¿Qué hace entonces su inteligente padrastro? Concibe una idea más digna de su cabeza que de su corazón. Con la connivencia y la ayuda de su esposa se disfrazó, cubrió esos ojos agudos con gafas tintadas, enmascaró la cara con un bigote y un par de bigotes tupidos, hundió esa voz clara en un susurro insinuante, y doblemente protegido a causa de la corta vista de la chica, se presenta como el señor Hosmer Angel, y aleja a otros amantes al enamorarla él mismo."
es_results: output>La mujer mayor, a pesar de su edad, mostraba una vitalidad inesperada y una curiosidad por la vida que sorprendía a muchos. La relación entre ella y su joven marido era extraña, pero funcional. Él, atraído inicialmente por los beneficios económicos, se había convertido en un compañero leal y cuidadoso, consciente de que su bienestar dependía en gran medida de su esposa.

en_results_raw: He was smoking furiously, and every now and then he drew his hand across his lips, as though to wipe away the evidence of his own thoughts. The room was full of tobacco smoke, and the air was heavy and hot. The ticking of the old clock upon the mantelpiece was the only sound which broke the stillness of the chamber. Holmes's brows were drawn down in profound thought, and his usually sharp and observant eyes were dull and listless. Dr. Watson, his companion, sat opposite him, watching his friend with a mixture of concern and curiosity. The detective had been in a peculiar mood all evening, restless and preoccupied, his mind clearly occupied with some intricate problem. Watson knew better than to disturb him when he was in such a state, for Holmes's mind was a delicate instrument, and any interruption could shatter his train of thought. The fire crackled and popped, casting flickering shadows across the walls, as Holmes continued to stare into its depths, lost in his contemplation. Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, he raised his head, his eyes now alight with a renewed spark of interest and determination. "Watson," he began, his voice low and intense, "I believe I have made a breakthrough in our case. The clues have been pointing towards a most unexpected culprit, one whose motives and methods have been shrouded in mystery until now. It is time to act, and we must do so swiftly before they have the chance to strike again." With that, Holmes rose from his chair, his mind already racing ahead, formulating the next steps in their investigation. Watson, ever the loyal companion, quickly followed suit, ready to assist Holmes in whatever perilous adventure lay ahead.

He paused for a moment, lost in thought, then continued, "The past weeks have been a web of deceit and danger, but tonight, the threads converge. en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. es_first_half: "Nos fuimos entonces, y condujimos durante al menos una hora. El coronel Lysander Stark había dicho que sólo eran siete millas, pero yo creía, por la velocidad a la que parecíamos ir, y por el tiempo que tardamos, que debían ser más de doce. Se sentó a mi lado en silencio todo el tiempo, y me di cuenta, más de una vez cuando miré en su dirección, que me estaba mirando con gran intensidad. Parece que las carreteras rurales no son muy buenas en esa parte del mundo, porque dimos unos bandazos y sacudidas terribles. Intenté mirar por las ventanillas para ver algo de dónde estábamos, pero eran de vidrio esmerilado, y no pude distinguir nada más que el borrón ocasional de una luz que pasaba. De vez en
es_second_half: cuando me arriesgaba a hacer algún comentario para romper la monotonía del viaje, pero el coronel sólo respondía con monosílabos, y la conversación pronto decaía. Por fin, sin embargo, los golpes de la carretera fueron sustituidos por la crujiente suavidad de un camino de grava, y el carruaje se detuvo. El coronel Lysander Stark se bajó de él y, mientras yo lo seguía, me arrastró a un porche que se abría ante nosotros. Bajamos, por así decirlo, del carruaje y entramos en el vestíbulo, de modo que no pude echar la más fugaz mirada a la fachada de la casa. En el instante en que crucé el umbral, la puerta se cerró de golpe detrás de nosotros, y oí débilmente el traqueteo de las ruedas mientras el carruaje se alejaba."

en_results_raw: “I find the stories of crime fascinating, as if they are puzzles waiting to be solved. The agony column, on the other hand, offers a glimpse into the private sorrows of others, a reminder that beneath the surface, everyone carries their own burdens. I am particularly drawn to the anonymous letters, where individuals pour out their hearts, seeking solace or advice. It's a curious habit, I know, but it provides a certain comfort, a connection to the world through shared suffering and intrigue. en_results: , I noticed something peculiar about the household. The mistress of the house, a Mrs. Merridew, seemed to be excessively concerned with my appearance and insisted on numerous changes to
en_results_raw: “You will find it rather disconnected, I fear, and there may prove to be little relation between the different incidents of which I speak. On the very first day that I was at the Copper Beeches, I noticed something peculiar about the household. The mistress of the house, a Mrs. Merridew, seemed to be excessively concerned with my appearance and insisted on numerous changes to my attire. Her husband, Mr. Merridew, was rarely seen, and when he was, he appeared distant and preoccupied. The children, though well-behaved, were unnaturally quiet and seemed to be under strict surveillance. The servants, too, moved about with a sense of unease, whispering among themselves and casting furtive glances in my direction. As days passed, I began to uncover a series of oddities that piqued my curiosity. The house itself was isolated, surrounded by high walls and dense foliage, which made it feel like a fortress rather than a home. Mrs. Merridew's obsession with my presence grew to the point where she insisted I stay in her room at night, claiming it was safer. This, coupled with the peculiar behavior of the household, led me to suspect that there was more to the Copper Beeches than met the eye. I decided to investigate further, taking care to be discreet. My inquiries led me to discover a hidden room in the attic, accessible only through a concealed door in Mrs. Merridew's bedroom. Inside, I found a young woman, clearly frightened and in distress. She revealed herself to be Agnes, Mr. Merridew's sister, who had been kept prisoner there for reasons unknown. The truth began to unravel as I pieced together the story: Agnes had been disinherited by her brother for reasons of pride and greed, and he had concocted this elaborate scheme to keep her hidden away, ensuring that his claim to the family fortune remained unchallenged. The bizarre behavior of the household, the isolation, and the constant surveillance were all part of his plan to maintain secrecy. Realizing the gravity of the situation, I resolved to help Agnes escape and bring her brother's actions to light. The ensuing events were a whirlwind of tension and danger, as Mr. Merridew and his accomplices attempted to thwart our efforts. However, with careful planning and a bit of luck, we managed to outwit them and secure Agnes' freedom. The resolution of the mystery at the Copper Beeches was both satisfying and unsettling, as it exposed the depths of human depravity and the lengths to which some will go to achieve their ends. In the aftermath, I reflected on the strange occurrences that had transpired, realizing that the disconnected incidents I had initially encountered were all threads in a much larger and darker tapestry. The experience left me with a profound sense of the importance of vigilance and the courage to confront injustice, lessons that would stay with me long after the mystery at the Copper Beeches had been laid to rest.”

tr_results_raw: bir dersle karşılaştım. Ders, "Tarih Bilimi" adıyla belirtilmişti ve öğretmenim, Dr. Bayrak, çok detaylı ve ilgi çekici bir şekilde konuyu ele alıyordu. Ders sırasında, antik kaynaklardan günümüze kadar uzanan bir tarih yolu izliyor olduk. Kitaplar, eserler ve belgeler üzerinden tarih boyunca yaşanan olayları keşfedinmiştim. Ancak, bir olayın diğerine nasıl etkisini anlamak, bu süreçte önemli bir adım oluşturur. Örneğin, Akgürgenler Konağı'nın tarihçesi, bölgesel siyasi ve ekonomik durumları etkilemiş olabilir. Bu bağlantılar, tarihi olayların daha derin ve karmaşık bir yorumuna yol açar. Ayrıca, kültürel ve coğrafi faktörler de bu tür olayların anlaşılmasında kritik rol oynar. Bu nedenle, her bir olayın kendi özgün yollarında incelenmesi, genel tarihsel bağlamda daha derinlemesine anlaşılmasına yardımcı olur. Bu süreçte, araştırma yetenekleri ve analitik düşünme becerileri geliştirilirken, tarihin zenginliklerini daha iyi kavrayabilmemiz için hayati önem taşır.
